description: Demolition of existing Public House and provision of 39 no. 1, 2 & 3 bed units (13 no. one-bedroom, 15 no. two-bedroom and 11 no. three-bedroom) up to 7 storeys in height together with 20 off-street car parking spaces, 244 sqm Class A1 retail space, new access/egress arrangements, hard and soft landscaping, cycle parking and refuse enclosures
decision_conditions: The proposed development fails to provide any affordable housing on-site, contrary to the findings of the Independent Viability Assessor which concluded that development could viably provide 28%  affordable dwellings on site. The proposal is therefore contrary to Policies H4 and H5 of the London Plan (2021) and Policy DM15 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

It has not been demonstrated, through the submission of robust or cogent information, that the proposed dwellings would provide a good standard of accommodation with good levels of daylight and amenity space and no dedicated playspace would be provided on-site for future occupants. The access arrangements for the duplex apartments are poor. The proposal is contrary to  Policies D4 and D6 of the London Plan (2021) and Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2021).

It has not been demonstrated that the proposed development  would conform with the scale, pattern or character of residential development in the area, or that the design and massing would sit uncomfortably with the surroundings. The proposed eastern block, due to its design, height and massing would appear incongruous and would not contribute positively to the surrounding townscape and would detract from the character and appearance of the area and the streetscene. As such the proposal is contrary to the NPPF (2019), Policies D3 and D4 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies DM10 and DM12 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

The proposal would represent an excessive and cramped form of development on this restricted site, as evidenced by site layout, which is dominated by hard landscaping, parking and access roads, with poor public realm; and it's separation from boundaries,  contrary to Policies D3, D4 and D8 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies DM10 and DM12 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

The proposal would result in an unacceptable loss of amenity for neighbouring residents by reason of loss of daylight, increase in overshadowing, overbearing impact and a loss of privacy to habitable rooms of dwellings on Haycroft Road and to 180/182 Hook Road. The proposal would therefore result in an unacceptable impact upon residential amenity and would conflict with the NPPF, Policy D6 of the London Plan (2021) and  policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD.

The proposal would result in the loss of a significant proportion of the existing employment floor space and a net loss of employment floorspace which would compromise the future viability of the site for employment purposes. The  proposal is  contrary to Policies CG 5 and SD 6 of the London Plan (2021) Policy DM17 of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted, April 2012.

The development would exacerbate parking stress in local roads and potentially impact highway safety due to congestion and vehicles backing up onto the A309. Additional highway safety concerns arise as a result of the potential for stopping on the Red Route to allow for deliveries and dropping off, due to the long distances between some of the residential units and the parking area. The proposal would be prejudicial to highway safety, contrary to Paragraph 109 of the NPPF (2019), Policy T4 and Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

The development would be unacceptable in terms of flood risk and could potentially increase flood risk to this development as well as those in the surrounding area. Contrary to the Paragraph 163 NPPF (2019), Policy SI12 of the London Plan (2021) and Policy DM4 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

It has not been robustly demonstrated that the proposed development would comply with the drainage hierarchy and that the proposed development would not increase flood risk on-site or elsewhere, contrary to Paragraph 163 and 165 of  the NPPF (2019), Policy SI 13 of the London Plan (2021) and Policy DM4 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

The applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent and up to date evidence that the proposed development would not harm protected species, contrary to the NPPF (2019) and the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended), The Protection of Badgers Act (1992) and the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations (2017), Policy G6 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM6 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

It has not been demonstrated that the proposal would protect the biodiversity value  of the site, or secure biodiversity net-gain. The proposal is therefore contrary to the NPPF, Policy G6 of the London Plan and Policy DM6 of the Core Strategy 2012.

The applicant has failed to robustly demonstrate that the site is unsuitable to provide a minimum of 30% of dwellings as 3 or more bedroom units and no robust arguments or evidence has been submitted to demonstrate that a policy compliant provision of 3 or more bedroom units would be unviable. The proposed development would fail to contribute towards meeting the objectively assessed need within the Borough for 3 bedroom units. The proposed development is therefore contrary to Policy DM13 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

No mechanism to secure the required net-zero carbon offsetting payment has been submitted and it has not been demonstrated that the minimum Urban Greening Factor target of 0.4 would be achieved on site.  It has therefore not been demonstrated that the proposed development would be zero carbon and would incorporate high-quality landscaping, contrary to Policies G5 and SI 2 of the London Plan (2021) and Policy DM3 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).
No robust evidence has been submitted to demonstrate that the proposed residential development would not be adversely impacted by poor air quality, contrary to Policy SI 1 of the London Plan (2021).

No Fire Statement has been submitted in support of the planning application and it has therefore not been demonstrated that the development would comply with the requirements of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021) in terms of fire safety and access for fire appliances.

The proposal fails to include at least 10 percent as wheelchair user dwellings to meet Building Regulation requirement M4(3), or to demonstrate that all other dwellings would meet Building Regulation requirement M4(2) (Accessible and Adaptable Dwellings). The proposal is contrary to Policy D7 (Accessible Housing) of the London Plan (2021).

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special CharacterProposalRemoval of an existing canopy over patio area and erection of veranda with glass roof.Consultation4 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character is a non-designated heritage asset.Paragraph 203 of the NPPF states that:The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer Comment: The proposed glass veranda would replace an exiting structure of lesser quality. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development and therefore no impact on The Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Due to the transparent nature of the development, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations4 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  2 letters of objection received and states : Excessive height or bulk of buildingsInappropriate design/ layoutLoss of light/ sunlightThese material considerations will be included within the assessment.  Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for the conversion of garage to habitable room, erection of single storey side infill and rear extensions. Installation of roof lights. Internal alterations and refurbishment.Application SiteThe  site comprises a detached dwelling. The application site  resides within Flood Zones 2, 3 and 3b. Planning Assessment The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact upon Highways- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer comment : The proposal seeks approval of the  conversion of garage to habitable room, erection of single storey side infill and rear extensions. Installation of roof lights. Internal alterations and refurbishment.The proposal seeks to convert the detached garage into a habitable room. This would result in the loss of the garage door  to be replaced by a window similar in appearance with the existing front elevation window of the dwelling. The existing parapet flat roof of the garage would be replaced by a pitch roof  to match the roof form styles  on the existing front elevation projection and the main dwelling. The principle of the conversion of the existing  detached garage to a habitable room is deemed acceptable.The dwelling benefits from an existing single storey rear extension which projects a depth of 2.5m and extends a width of 7.9m which merits a hipped roof.  The proposed extension would extend a width of 8.8m and project a depth of 6.23m . It would have a flat parapet roof of 4.7m in height  which would accommodate 3nos rooflights.. The proposal would result in a rear building line being in alignment with neighbouring no 39 Southwood Drive, however it is noted that the separation distance would be reduced to 1m. A side infill extension is proposed on the northern elevation allowing for the integration of the existing garage with the main dwelling and new windows are proposed with  two serving en suite bathrooms. The proposed materials would relate well to those of the existing dwelling.Officers note there is an inconsistency in the submitted drawings in respect of this aspect of the proposal. :Existing and proposed ground floor  and sections plans (drawing no 101-1)The garage has been repositioned further away from the  shared boundary with no 39 Southwood Drive which has not been  reflected in the description of development which only seeks approval for the conversion to a habitable roomProposed ground floor plan shows a staircase leading to an upper level. There is no submitted plan showing a proposed upper floor level. The introduction of roof lights on the east elevation pitch would suggest the roofspace is to be occupied. The proposed works have not been reflected in description of development Existing  and proposed side elevations drawing (drawing no 103-1)Annotation states the height of the proposed roof remains the same as existing . This is not reflected on the existing and proposed rear elevation as shown on the same drawingOn the same drawing (drawing no 103 -1) Officers also note the change of roof form between existing and proposed  which has not been addressed in the description of developmentGeneral The description of development does not reflect the scope of proposed works which have been identified on the submitted drawings No topographical levels of the site and the existing building have been provided Due to the submission of inconsistent and contradictory plans Officers are unable to fully assess the impact of the proposed development on the character appearance of the host dwelling or the immediate surrounding area. The applicant has therefore failed to demonstrate, through the submission of cogent information, that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact  in terms of character and appearance, in conflict with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8  and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012)Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The principal property to consider in relation to amenity is neighbouring property at nos 39 and 43 Southwood Drive.Officer Comment:  In light of the comment above on the inconsistent and contradictory plans, Officers are  unable to fully assess the impact of the proposed development on the neighbouring amenities of nos 39 and 43 Southwood Grove. The applicant has therefore failed to demonstrate, through the submission of cogent information, that the proposed development would not have an unacceptable adverse impact  in terms of neighbouring amenities, conflict with Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8 and DM10 of  the Core Strategy (2012) .Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety  and ensure that they are not adversely affected.The application involves the conversion of the existing garage space into a habitable room. Based on the existing floor plans, it does not appear to be of a size capable of fitting a modern car. Nevertheless, the area of hardstanding/ driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used as a car parking space, and so the loss of the garage would not result in the loss of a space that would impact upon highway safety.The proposals would result in the loss of internal storage space currently capable of storing cycles. The plans do not explicitly show any replacement cycle parking as part of the proposals. Notwithstanding, Officers consider that there would be sufficient space either to the front or rear of the property to accommodate a purpose built enclosure to the required standards to comply with Policy T5 of the London Plan, 2021, and a condition to this effect would be attached to any grant of planning permission to require the applicant to supply details of cycle parking facilities to the Council for approval.Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application is accompanied by a Flood Risk Assessment. The   site falls within Flood Risk Zone 3b (functional floodplain), Flood Risk Zone 3a  and Flood Zone 2 (medium probability) . Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officers note that  neither the accompanying Flood Risk Assessment or the submitted drawings state the existing topographical levels of the overall site or the finished floor levels of the existing dwelling .  On this basis, Officers are unable to accurately assess the proposal with regard to the level of associated flood risk and whether the deemed mitigation measures as set out in the FRA are appropriate.  In this context, we are unable to undertake the relevant assessment in the  context  of the NPPF ( 2023) , the guidelines set out in the Planning Practice Guidance and flood risk standing advice for local planning authorities, Policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the Core Strategy ( 2012). Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary  to the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Conversion of garage into habitable space, erection of single storey and part first floor rear extensions. Changes to fenestrations.Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed conversion of the garage into habitable room is considered to be in-keeping with the existing street scene. The proposed alterations that would include new timber cladding to the front elevation and to the pitched roof are considered to be acceptable in this case. While the proposed cladding would be visible from public vantage points, given its siting (the side extension is set back approximately 2m form the front building line of the host dwelling and the neighbouring property) it would not dominate the street view. The proposed single storey infill rear extension would be of similar depth to the existing one (approximately 3.4) and the total height would be approximately 4m. The contemporary roof form and timber cladding, due to its design and siting is considered to be acceptable.The proposed first floor infill extension, due to its modest scale and the proposed design considered to appear as a subordinate and proportionate addition to the host dwelling. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Loss of Car ParkingParagraph 115 of the NPPF, 2023 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate at least 1 off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. In relation to cycle parking, Officers note that a secure cycle parking could be possibly provided within the existing amenity space to compensate for the loss of the garage. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted the following drawings to demonstrate the proposed fire strategy:  P`F`R`01 Proposed Landscape Plan - Fire Strategy, P`F`R`02  Proposed Ground & First Floor Plans - Fire Strategy and P`F`R`03  Proposed Loft Floor & Roof Plans - Fire Strategy, which are considered to be acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.Consultation No response received. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- Development in the Green Belt- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Other MattersDevelopment in the Green BeltSection 13 (Protecting Green Belt Land) of the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (2023) states that the Government attaches great importance to Green Belts. The fundamental aim of Green Belt policy is to prevent urban sprawl by keeping land permanently open; the essential characteristics of Green Belts are their openness and their permanence. Inappropriate development is, by definition, harmful to the Green Belt and should not be approved except in very special circumstances.The NPPF (2023) is clear that "When considering any planning application, local planning authorities should ensure that substantial weight is given to any harm to the Green Belt".The NPPF (2023) Para 154 includes a closed list of certain forms of development which are considered not to be inappropriate in the Green Belt.  In this case, part "c" is applicable and states that:"c) the extension or alteration of a building provided that it does not result in disproportionate additions over and above the size of the original building;"Policy G2 of the London Plan (2021) sets out that the strongest protection should be given to London's Green Belt, in accordance with national guidance and inappropriate development should be refused, except in very special circumstances. Policies CS3 and DM5 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012) also state that development in the Green Belt will only be supported if it is in accordance with national guidance.Officer Comment: In this instance the proposed development is considered to constitute "an extension or alteration of a building". The garage would be demolished as part of the proposal. The garage is not an original part of the building. The original building occupies a floorspace of c.115 sqm, and the resultant extensions, the building as extended, would occupy around 162 sqm. The original building has a volume of c.237sqm sqm, and the resultant extensions, the building as extended, would have a volume c.340 cubic metres. This equates to a c. 40% increase in the floor areas and volume of the building. On balance it is considered that this would not be a disproportionate extension to the original building.  The gap at first floor in the built form to the side boundary of the site would be largely maintained with a small encroachment set back from the front building line. It is considered that the visual relief between buildings that currently exists would not be compromised and therefore the openness of the Green Belt would not be reduced which is an essential characteristic of the Green Belt. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposal does not fully follow the guiding principles of the Council's adopted LDF Residential Design SPD. However it is considered that in this instance the proposed extension in relation to the host property and the neighbouring properties would be a subordinate addition and of an architectural style sympathetic to the host property and its surroundings.  It is considered that proposal would detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area creating an incongruous addition to the host property.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties and would not result in a loss privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, or visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Other matters The applicant has submitted a fire safety strategy in support of the application. It is considered that this does not fully adddress the 6 criteria in sufficient detail set out the London Plan Policy D12 in regards to fire safety. It is recommmended that a fully detailed fire safety strategy be submitted and this should be secured by condition and the details of which shall be agreed in writing and the development should thereafter be implemented and maintained/operated in accordance with the approved details. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.
